title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for identifying surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by agency employees, with referrals to the Chief Financial Officer for action if deemed necessary. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" allows agency employees to identify surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority, which can be transferred to the Treasury for deficit reduction. Employees may receive a cash award for identifying such funds, and agencies must submit an annual report to the Office of Personnel Management. The Office of Personnel Management requires agencies to report on disclosures of fraud, waste, and surplus funds by employees, along with total savings and cash awards given. This information must be included in each agency's budget request to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management submits an annual report to Congress and the Government Accountability Office on Federal cost savings and awards. Additionally, the Director ensures the cash award program of each agency is in place. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013 requires agencies to comply with cash award programs and submit annual certifications to Congress. The Comptroller General must report on the program's operation every 3 years. Officers at level I of the Executive Schedule are prohibited from receiving cash awards. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013 mandates agencies to follow cash award programs and provide annual certifications to Congress. The Comptroller General must report on the program every 3 years. Level I Executive Schedule officers are barred from receiving cash awards. The amendment updates the table of sections for chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code. The amendment prohibits cash awards to certain officers under section 4509 of the Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013.
